qas.question: What was a significant contributor to the human food supply?
What did the supplementary meat from hunting include?

answers.text: protein, bone for implements, sinew for cordage, fur, feathers, rawhide and leather

qas.question: What was the leather from hunting used for?
Rocks and spears are examples of some of man's earliest what?
Hunt was a significant contributor to what?
Why is hunting still vital in marginal climates?

answers.text: unsuited for pastoral uses or agriculture

qas.question: How are the skins of sea mammals useful for people in the Arctic trap?
What did development of agriculture significantly contribute to?
What did the Inuit people first develop in the Arctic when meat was scarce?
What would the Inuit people use to decorate their clothing?
What would the Inuit women sometimes use to make jewelry?
What was the preferred weapon of the Inuit people for hunting?

context: Even as animal domestication became relatively widespread and after the development of <b10_0>agriculture<b10_0/>, <a0_0>hunting<a0_0/> was usually a significant contributor to <b9_0>the <a5_0>human food supply<b9_0/><a5_0/>. The supplementary meat and materials from hunting included <a1_0>protein, <b12_0>bone<b12_0/> for implements, sinew for cordage, fur, <b11_0>feathers<b11_0/>, rawhide and leather<a1_0/> used in <a2_0>clothing<a2_0/>. Man's earliest <a3_0>hunting weapons<a3_0/> would have included rocks, spears, the atlatl, and <b13_0>bows and arrows<b13_0/>. Hunting is still vital in <a4_0><a6_0>marginal climates<a6_0/><a4_0/>, especially those <a7_0>unsuited for pastoral uses or agriculture<a7_0/>.[citation needed] For example, Inuit people in the Arctic trap and hunt animals for clothing and use the skins of sea mammals to <a8_0>make kayaks, clothing, and footwear<a8_0/>.
